questions.question: Firmware that initializes hardware during the boot process before the OS loads.
questions.explanation: BIOS performs hardware initialization at startup.

questions.question: Modern replacement for BIOS with more features and security.
questions.explanation: UEFI provides faster boot times and better security than BIOS.

questions.question: Component that processes graphics and video output.
questions.explanation: The GPU handles rendering of images, videos, and animations.

questions.question: Slot on the motherboard used to add expansion cards.
questions.explanation: PCIe slots allow adding graphics cards, network cards, and other expansions.

questions.question: Small amount of fast memory inside the CPU for quick data access.
questions.explanation: Cache stores frequently accessed data for faster processing.

questions.question: The speed at which a CPU executes instructions, measured in GHz.
questions.explanation: Clock speed indicates how many cycles per second the CPU can perform.

questions.question: Multiple CPUs on a single chip working together.
questions.explanation: Multi-core processors have multiple processing units for parallel tasks.

questions.question: Interface connecting storage devices to the motherboard using cables.
questions.explanation: SATA is the standard interface for HDDs and SSDs.

questions.question: File system commonly used by Windows operating systems.
questions.explanation: NTFS is the primary file system for modern Windows.

questions.question: Battery-powered memory that stores BIOS settings.
questions.explanation: CMOS stores system configuration even when powered off.
